title: Not a beach or infinity pool in sight: The photographer who captured mesmerising beauty in everyday life around the world
text:
63 shares 6
View
comments
Photographer Matjaz Krivic set out in 2002 to capture scenes of 'beauty and emotion' in countries around the world - and it's safe to say that his project has been a success.
These stunning images by the Slovenian photographer portray stark reality and quiet moments intertwining with the developing world.
On his travels, the Slovenian photographer found personal moments within an increasingly impersonal world.
Otherworldly: The morning mist rises eerily from the valley towards a small town in the Haraz mountains. This image was shot just after a sunset on the roof of a palace at Shugruf village. The scene lasted only for a few seconds and Krivic was able to get just one shot
A pilgrim during his ritual washing in Lake Sarovar, in the centre of which stands the famous Sikh temple Hari Mandir, the golden temple
Adventurous day out: Kids playing on the main minaret of the Grand Mosque in Bani using precariously posts as footholds
'My photographs disclose an individual who is more important than the sacred found in these places, an individual who lives within a community of people that he or she accompanies or defies,' the Slovenian photographer explained to MailOnline Travel.
'Even when we turn our gaze away from the photograph and close our eyes, we can still hear the story of this individual.
'I search for moments that portray some beauty and emotion — often filled with silence and grandeur. Whether it is a face, a motion, a mountain, bridge, or temple.'

From students studying in decaying classrooms, to a dog curled up on warm rubbish by the Ganges, his UrbaniStan photographs capture genuine and unposed moments.
The extensive portfolio includes work dating back to 2002, from a total of 15 countries.
'It would be really hard to pick just one favourite image, since all the photos carry some kind of emotional memory,' he said.
'But some images never fail to amaze me. Those would be the devotion of Tibetan monks, the biblical serenity of life of Yemeni people, the esoteric rituals of Sufi mystics in Iran and Pakistan, the simplicity of Mali tribes' live and the emotionally charged ceremonies on the river Ganges in Varanasi, India.'

Religion plays a strong part in the series, with one poignant photograph showing a mother and daughter peacefully curled up on the floor of the Virupaksha Temple in Hampi during a traditional religious festival.
Ritual washing features in a striking image of a bearded pilgrim bathing in Lake Sarovar, in the centre of which stands the famous Sikh temple Harmandir Sahib, the golden temple.
The photographer is currently working in Burkina Faso in Africa on a new project called Digging the Future which demonstrates life in the Burkina Faso artisanal gold mines.
Krivic can be followed on his website , the project's page , his Twitter and Facebook .
